channel.title: Kim Aava on ArtStation
channel.description: Lead 3D Artist & Principal Artist @ EA DICE

item.title: New Timelaps up! Antler Deer Knife! by Kim Aava
item.content:encoded:
A new timelaps complied from when streaming the Antler Deer Knife for Art Jam 02! Check it out here on Youtube!

If you are interested in seeing old streams? Check out my Patreon page for how to access the Stream Archive!

item.title: Art Blog #010 Saddle Bag Texture WIP by Kim Aava
item.content:encoded:
Doctor's Saddle Bag texture WIP

Started texturing the Doctor's Saddle Bag and thought it was time to share some more WIP.

I also never tried using anchor points in substance, had to try it out this project and it's really nice for layering of damage, once you get it working.


Base layers added for color and type of micro details


Additional colors and rough detail start of the metal

First rough pass of main leather parts

Second detail pass on main leather



Overall progress for the entire bag

So still a lot of thing lefts to do but I'm making progress!

item.title: Art Blog #009 Doctor's Saddle Bag - Progress and taking it one step further by Kim Aava
item.content:encoded:
Lowpolys, UVs and bakes are done! I have started texturing and there are still some work left to do before it's done. Mostly polish work on the texture and lighting.

Lowpoly + bakes

Lowpoly + Bakes + ID map

Lowpoly + Bakes with wireframe

First texture pass
  

I also feel it's a bit mundane and boring with all the brown leather, so I have started looking into expanding it to a smaller prop scene. Like adding herbs, spices etc to get some color contrast going. Both herb in the bottles but also scattered outside. As well as adding funny labels.

Thing I consider adding below:

item.title: Art Blog #008 Pot Diorama Finished! Now Next Project! by Kim Aava
item.content:encoded:
Pot Diorama

I finally managed to get the Pot Diorama done! Phew it took a while but I can now close this chapter of my life and move onto the next project. 

Check it our here if you haven't already!


Doctor's Saddle Project!

I started this one a while back when I was running the ArtJam03, but as I went back to finish the Pot Diorama I had put this one on hold in the meantime. Time has now come to finish this one as well, before moving on to something entirely new. 

I'm currently adding the final details of the sculpt before moving onto some good ol' retopo aka making the lowpoly.

Reference Board for the Doctor's saddle bag.

Maya block out mixed with finished highpoly base for sculpting. I usually make my blockout and highpoly in Zbrush only, but since this one had very straight shapes and could be easily done in maya with curves I used a bit more old school method this time.

Highpoly screen grabs from Zbrush

item.title: Pot Diroama by Kim Aava
item.description:
This Pot Diorama is a a twitch streaming project I started last year.
It feels like it took ages to finish this piece, tho I also only work on it while streaming. Even thought about calling it quits a few times but as my own advice is to always see something through to the end, I finally finished it

Additionally we had a discord community challenge, were everyone who made a frog would be featured here on my Artstation and in the renders of this diorama! You will find the frogs a bit further down on the page. Please show some love to these lovely artists by following their Artstations! <3

Why did I include the other peoples work in my diorama? I think it's important to show appreciation and help each other grow <3
https://www.artstation.com/snnkmcl
https://www.artstation.com/thole
https://www.artstation.com/abraxocleaner
https://www.artstation.com/impact
https://www.artstation.com/flatronw2042s

Interested in seeing my streams? Here's the link https://www.twitch.tv/aavachan
To see old streams, I have a Patreon were everything end up in a streaming archive https://www.patreon.com/aavachan

item.title: I'm on Patreon! + CubeBrush by Kim Aava
item.description: I just started a Patreon!
item.content:encoded:
I'm on Patreon!

Yes! It's true! I started a Patreon site to more easily give back to all my supporters! I never felt that the Twitch emotes were enough as a thank you.



In the future I want to explore more content for Patreon, perhaps trying a mentor program? or make small tutorials? I'm currently asking around to see what people would be interested in and what an reasonable amount would be as compensation. 

So if anyone reading this, have any suggestions or comments for content, please drop a line below and let me know :D


In addition I also decided to start a store at Cubebrush

Just made the first small drop, Stylized Plank IMM Brush. Which Btw are free for Patreon Hero Supporters :3

Stay safe everyone! <3

item.title: Battlefield V Live - Wake Island by Kim Aava
item.description:
During Battlefield V Live I stepped into a new role as a lead 3D Artist.during live production my responsibilities included, but where not limited to: planning, scoping, assigning tasks, leading a smaller art team, setting up pipelines and workflows, educating and guiding junior artist and partner teams, assisting tech art, polish and bug-fixing.
All levels/maps have been a collaborative team effort across multiple disciplines, in-house and outsourcing. Thanks to everyone who put their effort into making it a wonderful experience!

item.title: Art blog #007 Third Art Jam Results! by Kim Aava
item.content:encoded:
Third community Art Jam has come to an end! As with previous Art Jams the participants got to choose between the three concepts below. The rules are simple, to make a game ready assets that either looks like the reference or to interpret in their own way!

The Art Jam was running from Feb 27th to April 26th and you will find the amazing submissions below! Don't forget to check out the artists and give them a follow and/or like! Or even drop a comment! <3 We all knows that being recognized brings a smile to our faces :D

Concept Art: Anna Shulgina, Svyatoslav Dobrovolsky and from a Live auction house

Submissions:

Gnarly Potato

Ditte Galsgaard

Robert Paseka

Magnus Evertsen

Yoshua James

Boris Gubanov

item.title: Deer Antler Knife - Kofun period by Kim Aava
item.description:
This is made as a personal project during a Art Jam that I hosted on my twitch channel. It's a Japanese Deer Antler Knife from the Kofun Period. During my trip to Japan this summer I found some really cool old objects in museums, I just couldn't resist taking photos and start model this once home again. I also wanted to challenge myself, so I spend a long time on handsculpting most of it with trim smooth border and trim dynamic. Only exception is the pattern which I drew in photoshop and made an alpha from.

https://www.twitch.tv/aavachan

item.title: Artblog #006 by Kim Aava
item.content:encoded:
Woah! Time fly fast! Like it's been month since I updated my art blog! :O

Twitch Stream

Let's start with a big announcement! I am now streaming on Tuesdays and Thursdays 9pm CET!

A new thing I want to try is to theme the streams. Reason is that I want to allocate time to work on personal projects as previously, but also learn new skills and softwares that I seldom have the time to do. So .... 

Tuesdays - Project Art aka working on personal project in the same fashion as before (environment, diorama, props etc) 

Thursdays - 'LevelUp w Aavachan', I will be learning new skills myself, softwares and just trying out stuff that I have no idea how to do.  

Stylized Taurus Chest

I finished my Taurus Chest Streaming project! Stylization is always something I enjoy very much doing so as always it was really fun doing this piece. More Final renders can be found on my Artstation page :)

 

Concept Art was based on Elena Savchenko awesome render and design!

Streaming Project 

So the current streaming project I'm working on is a mini Pot Diorama. I found this cute fountain that has a couple of pots stacked on top of each others. I started this one just before summer vacation and figured I would continue the adventure with it on Tuesday streams. Below are some WIP from the past streams as well as the reference. So How did you start? Glad you asked! :D

I started by doing a blockout in Zbrush with Zmodeler, once I had proportion and shapes nailed down I continued by sculpting some rocks. My favorite part of sculpting rocks are using Trim Smooth Border and Clay Buildup! I love hand sculpting rocks so I seldom use Alphas. After the rocks were done, I experimented with hand drawing some lines on the pots, at first I figured that I would just tile a line pattern with height info in substance painter, but I had too much fun to not sculpt it. I also started adding some insect, trying to bring some extra life into the scene.

  

LevelUp with Aavachan Stream!

As my first LevelUp Stream i decided to go for Substance Deisgner. I never really get the chance to properly test out the program and just sit down and learn. So I figured, what's an better way of learning than streaming and being coached by the chat! Huge thanks to the entire chat for keeping me company and giving me some really useful tips and tricks!

I will try to keep these Art blog a little bit more up to date moving forward! It's also a great way form me to track my own progress as well :3

item.title: Artblog #005 Nordic Envionment Update! by Kim Aava
item.description: WIP Nordic Diorama, showing some of my composition, 3D concepting and my blockout iteration
item.content:encoded:
Progression Progression!

I'm still trying to figure out the layout, composition , level of details and the general concept of things. It's nice to just do fast and dirty speedmodels as it's quick to mock up new things and try out various designs. 

The latest direction is to remove the stone head, sad as it is (may the stone head rest in peace). The only reason why I kept the head in there for so long was to make it work with the "remake" of my old environment. Seeing as things have already changed a lot, it's no longer really just a simple remake, it's almost an entire different diorama piece. I'm now playing with a suggestion I got from one of my viewer (during a streaming session) to go for a ornamented door or just a carving in the mountain. Keep it simple, keep it clean. Let the diorama breath a little and lead the eye towards the pond/tree.

Blockout + Speedmodel iterations

Quick blockout is helpful for determine the initial layout and sizes, does't really tell me much about the composition or how the various individual object plays together. By iterating on each piece to the same amount of details all the time, moving in between the objects, it helps giving a hint on the potential final look. 

As with the head being out of the picture, I didn't end up wasting that much time and can continue on finding a solution that would fit the overall scene more.

A lot of my later speedmodels consist of super quick-low-res zbrush mehses, as the example to the right (latest speedmodel iteration). Sometimes I already have a library for speedmodel meshes and sometimes I have to make them quickly, like the tree example below (made quick speedmodel bark pieces to test out if it would be a potential look combined with roots).


 Cheers!

item.title: Artblog #004 Crossbow breakdown by Kim Aava
item.description: Asset Breakdown of Stylized Crossbow
item.content:encoded:
FINALLY! It's done .____.

So that took some time, not in hours spend on the asset itself, but in just finding time (hectic life) to just do it. This was the second asset of my stream, after the completion of the SkullBarrel. Somewhere along the way I lost interest in completing it and moved onto the my third project, The Nordic Diorama. I have so many unfinished assets in my folders, and it kept nagging me that I have just left it unfinished, especially since it was a streaming piece that people had expressed interest in seeing done. So again, FINALLY, I mustered my energy and found some time and it's now done! It always feels so much better to complete your personal projects, even if it takes almost a year to find the time. I wish I could manage myself to do that more often.

With that little rant (but also pat on my own shoulder), I want to share a short breakdown of my work progress for this asset.

The crossbow itself is based on the concept art from Becca Hallstedt 


So now I'm gonna look for another small stylized prop to make on the side, while working on my Nordic Diorama project, perhaps there's something old somewhere in my folders that could serve this purpose :3

item.title: Art blog #003 New Project by Kim Aava
item.content:encoded:
So new project! Thought it was about time to update the Art-blog with some WIP from the previous streaming sessions.

First stream was all about moodboard and reference gathering, putting pieces together and figuring out the direction for the scene. Keeping the theme and spirit of my old student project, while improving on overall layout and composition. I quickly made a blockout to starts to visualize the shapes and construction (I can't draw so I always do blockout in several steps, but always start with really blocky shapes).

So the diorama kinda increased in size (I always start grand and then scale down). Last stream I took the blockout a step further and started to refine and improve on it, making very rough and quick shapes in zbrush, to see the silhouette a bit better. This process also helps me determine which pieces that should be modular and what requires a more unique touch. 

So the layout is starting to shape up, but there quite some steps left before I feel that I am done with the 3d concepting phase and can move onto some proper modelling. At the moment I have a Nordic setting with some star gazing stone to the side, a gigantic stone carved head (I know looks like a creepy baby face right now!), wooden logs to form a stair; sunken into mud, mossy cliff formation in the background with some rune stones ornaments. 

So next step is to grasp the story. Why and for what purpose did someone build this? Is it a ceremonial? A meeting place? Maybe they just started construing everything and nothing is really completed yet?

I also started to consider using Unreal Engine for this project, instead of the initial plan to render it in Marmoset Toolbag as the old diorama is. I feel I might need material blending and be able to paint moss etc, something that isn't really supported in Marmoset (there are some community made scripts though.) However, it was a long time ago I used Unreal, so that would be something I need to investigate in before starting to import the blockout pieces into an engine.

Until next update, cheers!

item.title: "Det va länge sedan!" Updates! by Kim Aava
item.content:encoded:
"Det va länge sedan!" As we would say in Swedish. It's been long hours of work in the summer heat, but there's finally lights in the end of the tunnel. It started quite hectic for me, 5 moths at DICE have passed by in a blink of an eye. Battlefield V is almost done, and we can finally start going back to our everyday life after work.

Yesterday I started streaming again (Yes finally after being radio silent for a while!) I have a new streaming schedule that I will update now and then, but for now I will mostly keep it on Tuesdays. Hopefully I will be able to squeeze in some more days here and there.

(Speed sculpt of a ham on a plank stabbed with a knife! Why?! Well hat's how my throat felt yesterday due to my cold)

So as a new fresh start of the season I decided to start on a new project! I saw that the artstation challenge started again and considered participating in one for real this time. But! Since I'm quite aware that life has it's ways of getting-in-the-way, I decided against it. Instead, while pondering on what to do next, I looked at my old student work and thought "urk what the actual f--- did you think when you created this":

(4 year old student piece, that I will remake with my new mastered skills!!)

Some of you have probably seen it on my Artstation page and/or portfolio. It is an old student project of mine, 4 years old now (☉_☉) (time just fly!!) We had to make something for the Zbrush course in school (yes I was learning Zbrush with this piece) and I was also panicking as I needed something for my portfolio. Quixel came out at that time as well, so I baked it down on dirty geo and just slapped on procedural materials, put a light in marmoset and voilà! ¯\_(ツ)_/¯  So what's with this story then? Well! My new project is to make a new diorama with the same type of theme, Nordic (but proper Nordic and no "mumbo jumbo"... can anyone see the Asian inspired dragon in there...*face palm*) So starting next week, I will stream while working on a brand new project :)

Cheers! <3

item.title: ART Blog #002 Stream update! Stylized Crossbow as next project by Kim Aava
item.content:encoded:
So it's summer and even in Sweden we are melting in the heat!

I started my new job at DICE just 2 month ago (exactly on the day on Saturday 14th of June woop woop!). I have been quite busy with learning the ropes but I have still tried to be online and stream once a week.

I'm now working on a new piece, since I finished the skull barrel one already! (Yay!)

This time the concept is from Becca Hallstedt, a stylized crossbow. I'm making it in a similar fashion as the skull barrel, same type of stylization :)

Below are some WIP pics from my stream and the current state of the project. Only thing left to do now is the cloth pieces and the ropes, which I plan to wrap up in the next streaming session.

I didn't manage to finish it just yet, but I will when I need a break from working with the Wild West Challenge! Which I also will be streaming while working on. So If you are interested then feel free to follow me on twitch :)

item.title: Hello World! by Kim Aava
item.description: First blog entry with some links to articles written by me, covering subject of VR and Stylization vs Realism in game art.
item.content:encoded:
First blog post here at Artstation!  I have a lot of updates I want to share, but who would read a 5000+ word long blog post, right? So I decided to link my recent articles I have been working on and then just start to use this blog to post frequent updates!

So I quite recently released two articles at 80LV! It covers the methods and know-how of our approach to the stylization in realism of the art in Apex Construct as well as one for VFX and animation breakdown.

Apex Construct. Part 1: Stylization in Realism

Apex Construct Part 2: VFX, UI and Animation in VR



If you are interested in reading more about realism and stylization, I wrote an article last year covering my take and methods for working with realism and stylization. It's an article I wrote as a summary of my breakfast talk I held at DICE, If you like to read it you find a link below!

Realism vs Stylized


Speaking of DICE, many thought when the article was first published (and a lot of people asked) that I was an Artist at DICE. At that time I was still working for Fast Travel Games, developing Apex Construct. Well I am very excited to say that I am actually starting to work at DICE in May! So hopefully I will be sharing some cool stuff from there the coming year!

item.title: Apex Construct Machines by Kim Aava
item.description:
These machines are part of the end game in which the player is suppose to destroy. Making animated objects for VR in a stylized style was quite challenging, but also very fun to see and interact with once done right.

item.title: Apex Construct Envionment by Kim Aava
item.description:
A selection of envionments assets and props I made for the game, combined into a small diorama. It was fun to recreate parts of Stockholm in a stylized fashion.

©2018 Apex Construct is a trademark of Fast Travel Games.
item.content:encoded:
A selection of envionments assets and props I made for the game, combined into a small diorama. It was fun to recreate parts of Stockholm in a stylized fashion.

©2018 Apex Construct is a trademark of Fast Travel Games.

Highpoly sculpt of cliff and rock parts


Highpoly sculpt tiling textures and building parts

item.title: Apex Construct End Boss by Kim Aava
item.description:
During the development of Apex Construct I had the chance to design, model and texture the end boss for the game. All robots in the game have been design to represent animals with emphasis on animals that can be found in Sweden since the game's main setting is based upon Stockholm. I had a real fun time modelling this enemy from 3d concept to final in game model.

If you wish to see more of the the art of Apex Construct, make sure to check out Fast Travel Games main account or my fellow colleagues!
https://www.artstation.com/fasttravelgames

©2018 Apex Construct is a trademark of Fast Travel Games.

item.title: Apex Construct Bow by Kim Aava
item.description:
During the development of Apex Construct I had the chance to design, model and texture the hero weapon used throughout the game. The bow was designed to be a chunky mechanical bow to fit the setting of robots and the fact that the players has a robotic hand. I also had the opportunity to design, model and texture the organic players hand.

Robotic hand and arrow is made by my colleague Joacim Lunden, a senior artist at Fast Travel Games

©2018 Apex Construct is a trademark of Fast Travel Games

I also had the opportunity to design, model and texture the organic players hand.

Robotic hand and arrow is made by my colleague Joacim Lunden, a senior artist at Fast Travel Games

item.title: Realism vs. Stylized by Kim Aava
item.description:
I recently held my Realism vs. Stylized lecture as a guest speaker at DICE, and together with 80.lv I made a summary of what I covered during that talk. I hope you enjoy it and also find it useful!

Link here: https://80.lv/articles/realistic-vs-stylized-technique-overview/

item.title: Horizon: Zero Dawn - Train boogie by Kim Aava
item.description:
Train boogie highpoly made for Horizon: Zero dawn. I had the honor to do the highpoly for this piece which served as a benchmark asset for the outsourcing vendors and ended up in the final game for the Ruins old world theme. The outsourcing artists took this piece applied an aging rust pass and made the low poly and textures. Special thanks to my Lead Alex Zapata Assets Art Director (https://www.artstation.com/artist/lexisflex73) for mentoring me during my time at Guerrilla Games and to Björn Kjerrgren Technical Asset Artist who provided me with these renders.

©2017 Sony Interactive Entertainment Europe. Horizon Zero Dawn is a trademark of Sony Interactive Entertainment America LLC. Developed by Guerrilla

item.title: Horizon: Zero Dawn - Highpoly Assets by Kim Aava
item.description:
This is a small selection of sculpts I made for Horizon: Zero Dawn, either created entirely by myself or in part kitbashed as detailed at the bottom. Credits to the concept-team for creating fun and challenging concepts to work from, and to the artists at the outsourcing studios for providing brushes and sculpts. Special thanks to my Lead Alex Zapata Assets Art Director for mentoring me during my time at Guerrilla Games. Also to Björn Kjerrgren Technical Asset Artist who helped me execute my tasks with confident and for who providing me with these renders.

Torch, Candles and Bowl - made as a cinematic prop for the trailers and ingame for the Nora tribe theme. Sculpt is made by me except for hay and bottom handle rope of the torch, which is provided by the outsourcing vendors. Pot with food, Mug and Small brush - ingame assets made by me
©2017 Sony Interactive Entertainment Europe. Horizon Zero Dawn is a trademark of Sony Interactive Entertainment America LLC. Developed by Guerrilla

item.title: Horizon: Zero Dawn - Game Assets by Kim Aava
item.description:
A small selection of game assets I made for Horizon: Zero Dawn. The torch, candles and the candle bowl is made for cinematic purpose as well as ingame use. All textures and models, including lods are made by me, except for the birch wood with rope that was made by the talented outsourcing artists. Credits to the fantastic in-house concept artist for providing outstanding designs and fun to create concepts. Special thanks to my Lead Alex Zapata Assets Art Director (https://www.artstation.com/artist/lexisflex73) for mentoring me during my time at Guerrilla Games. Also to Björn Kjerrgren Technical Asset Artist who helped me execute my tasks with confident and for who providing me with these renders.

©2017 Sony Interactive Entertainment Europe. Horizon Zero Dawn is a trademark of Sony Interactive Entertainment America LLC. Developed by Guerrilla

item.title: Horizon: Zero Dawn - Watch Tower by Kim Aava
item.description:
I had the honor to do the wood textures and a polish texture pass on the roof as well as the ropes for this Nora tribe watch tower.
Thanks to the in-house concept artist for making the concept and to the environment team for assembling the tower from the modular pieces. Also credits to the outsourcing artist for making the sculpts and game meshes.

©2017 Sony Interactive Entertainment Europe. Horizon Zero Dawn is a trademark of Sony Interactive Entertainment America LLC. Developed by Guerrilla
item.content:encoded:
I had the honor to do the wood textures and a polish texture pass on the roof as well as the ropes for this Nora tribe watch tower.
Thanks to the in-house concept artist for making the concept and to the environment team for assembling the tower from the modular pieces. Also credits to the outsourcing artist for making the sculpts and game meshes.

©2017 Sony Interactive Entertainment Europe. Horizon Zero Dawn is a trademark of Sony Interactive Entertainment America LLC. Developed by Guerrilla
